definition:
Let $R$ be a ${\mathbb{Z}}_2$-graded ring (or more generally, an
associative algebra). We say that $R$ is [*supercommutative*]{} if for
any homogeneous elements $a$ and $b\in R$:

$$ab=(-1)^{\deg a\deg b}ba.$$

In other words, even homogeneous elements are in the center of the ring,
and odd homogeneous elements anti-commute.

Common examples of supercommutative rings are the exterior algebra of a
module over a commutative ring (in particular, a vector space) and the
cohomology ring of a topological space (both with the standard grading
by degree reduced mod 2).
